required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation (APBI) Using Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT)
clinical_study.official_title: Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation (APBI) Using Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT): a Multicenter, Observational Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
The recently updated National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Guidelines for Invasive Breast Cancer (Version 1.2021) includes Accelerated Partial Breast Irradiation (APBI) delivered by external beam methods in its Principles of Radiation Therapy section.
Studies of APBI suggest that rates of local control in selected low-risk patients with early-stage breast cancer may be comparable to those treated with standard Whole Breast Irradiation. Utilizing real-time image guidance, noncoplanar fields and respiratory tracking, SBRT should allow for less normal tissue in the Planning Target Volume (PTV). potentially reducing radiation-induced secondary tumors, toxicity to the lung, breast, heart, and unacceptable cosmesis.
The primary endpoint of this registry study will be assessment of breast cosmesis and toxicity following SBRT. Secondary endpoints will include assessment of ipsilateral breast recurrences and overall survival. Our goal is to accrue at least 200 patients to the study.

detailed_description.textblock:
STUDY OBJECTIVES SBRT for treatment of the surgical cavity following partial mastectomy for women with early-stage breast cancer will be studied. Target motion assessment and correction, non-coplanar beam arrangement and stereotactic dose delivery will be required. Ipsilateral breast cosmesis, dose to adjacent organs at risk, and acute and late toxicities of treatment will be assessed.
ENDPOINTS The primary endpoints of this study are the assessments of acute and late toxicities and breast cosmesis following SBRT. Secondary endpoints will include ipsilateral breast recurrences and overall survival.
ELIGIBILITY Inclusion Criteria
1. Women 50 years or older
2. Low to intermediate grade DCIS or invasive ductal carcinoma
3. Tumor size < 2 cm invasive ductal carcinoma and < 2.5 cm DCIS
4. Well defined lumpectomy cavity on CT
5. Clear surgical ink margins > 2mm for invasive cancer and > 3 mm for DCIS
6. Node negative
7. Unifocal lesion
8. ER and/or PR positive
9. HER-2 negative
10. BRCA negative
11. Lumpectomy cavity must be < 30% of whole breast volume
Exclusion Criteria
1. Lobular histology
2. Angiolymphatic invasion
3. Multiple foci of disease
4. Lymphovascular invasion
5. Active lupus or sarcoid
6. Distant metastases
7. Non-epithelial malignancies
8. Synchronous contralateral breast cancer
9. Grade 2 or higher oncoplastic surgery
10. Ipsilateral pacemaker
11. Ipsilateral breast implant
12. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy
13. Prior ipsilateral breast cancer or thoracic radiation
14. Poor breast integrity
15. Paget's Disease of the nipple
16. Pregnant patients
17. Severe cardiac, pulmonary, or liver diseases
RADIATION TREATMENT GUIDELINES and DOSIMETRY Fiducial Placement Prior to enrollment, patients will undergo breast conservation surgery preferably with fiducial markers implanted at the time of surgery or under ultrasonic guidance25
1. Patients treated with gantry-based SBRT preferably will have fiducials placed at the time of surgery.
2. For patients being treated with CyberKnife SBRT, four gold markers will be placed intraoperatively or ultrasonically to define the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral boundaries of the lumpectomy cavity in accordance with the manufacturer's (Accuray) documentation. At least three fiducials will be required for target tracking purposes to allow for rotational changes.
Simulation Linear Accelerator SBRT For treatments on a gantry-based linear accelerator, patients will be positioned supine with the arms elevated. CT scans will be obtained with 1.25 mm thickness and will be acquired with free breathing as well as additional scans as needed for motion control or gating. 4DCT, MRI and PET imaging may be used to assist in determining motion estimation.
CyberKnife SBRT For treatment on a robotic system, a contrast enhanced CT simulation is to be performed with 1 mm slices with the patient's arms at her sides in the supine position. The scan is to be performed with end-inspiratory breath hold from the thyroid to below the lungs. Breast immobilization devices including a vacuum mattress and a bra system will be allowed however bolus should not be used. Fiducial tracking (Synchrony) is to be used for motion tracking.
DOSIMETRY Target and Organs at Risk (OAR) contours
The following structures are to be contoured in all patients:
- Tumor cavity (GTV) as defined on CT including all fiducials implanted on CT images
- Clinical Target Volume (CTV) defined as the tumor cavity expanded by a uniform 15 mm margin. The CTV will not extend beyond the skin, breast or chestwall
- Planning Tumor Volume (PTV) for SBRT will be defined as the CTV plus 3 - 5 mm as needed at the treating physician's discretion. PTV will be limited to GTV plus 20 mm margin
- Skin is defined as <5 mm inside the external contour
- Chest wall includes the ribs and intercoastal musculature but does not include the pectoralis
- Heart contour begins below the level of where the pulmonary trunk branches into the left and right pulmonary arteries
- Lungs are to be contoured separately
- Spinal canal
- Breasts are to be contoured separately
Dose Prescription The total prescribed dose to the PTV is 30 Gy delivered in 5 equal fractions of 6 Gy per day delivered on alternating days over 5 -10 total days. The prescribed dose must cover at least 95% of the PTV.
OAR Constraints
- PTV- 100% > 28.5 Gy (95% of the prescribed dose); Max dose to 0.03 cc <105% of the prescribed dose; < 105% to <15% of PTV
- Ipsilateral whole breast - < 50% will receive < 15 Gy; Limit breast volume to < 1000 cc. The Lumpectomy cavity must be < 30% of whole breast volume
- Contralateral breast - <3% of the prescribed dose to any point
- Ipsilateral lung - < 10% to receive 10 Gy
- Contralateral lung - < 5% to receive 5 Gy
- Heart - < 10% receives > 3 Gy
- Skin - 0.03 cc receives no more than 36 Gy
- Chest Wall - 0.03 cc receives no more than 36 Gy
- OAR within 5% of the listed constraints will be acceptable
Target Tracking Optical Surface Monitoring Systems, cone-beam CT, electromagnetic transponders, on-board MRI, or fiducial motion tracking using kV imaging must be available to monitor respiratory motion during treatment.
PATIENT ASSESSMENT Follow up visits will be done at 4-6 weeks, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months, 24 months and then yearly to 5 years. Patient's will have a history and physical, yearly mammogram. Other investigations will only be done based upon suspicious symptoms or signs. Treatment toxicity will be based on CTCAE version 4.0 and cosmesis based on global cosmetic score (GCS) by the NRG-RTOG by both patient and physician. The GCS is a 4-point scale: 1-Excellent, 2-Good, 3-Fair, 4-Poor. Digital photos of both breasts and closeup of the treated breast will be taken at baseline and that each follow up and visit and will be rated using the Harvard Cosmesis Scale (HCS). The HCS is also a 4-point scale that compares symmetry, color and scar comparing the treated and untreated breast.
DATA MANAGEMENT Patient data will be collected by a designated staff member at each treating facility and entered in the Registry for Performance and Clinical Outcomes in Radiosurgery in the breast SBRT subsection. RPCR, Inc. (radiosurgery-registry.com) is a not-for-profit, 501c-6 organization, partnered with Doorn Corporation to handle the registry's data collection and analytics. Doorn will provide management, support and maintenance of the registry for all participating sites accessing the registry. The RPCR's database offers multi-level data encryption, HIPAA compliance and is SSAE 18 certified.
IRB APPROVAL All participating sites will be required to obtain IRB approval prior to enrollment of any patients. If no local IRB is available, a group IRB approved protocol can be joined. IRB-approve patient consent will be obtained by the treating physician.

primary_outcome.description: physician and patient assessment of breast cosmetic result following SBRT
assessment of skin and breast tissue changes during and immediately following SBRT
assessment of pulmonary, cardiac and chest wall changes following SBRT

clinical_study.condition: Acute and Late Toxicities and Breast Cosmesis

intervention.description: Treatment technique used to deliver a highly focused and accurate radiation dose to a defined target volume outside the brain; the entire course of therapy delivered in five fractions or less

study_pop.textblock: SBRT for treatment of the surgical cavity following partial mastectomy for women with early-stage breast cancer will be studied.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Women 50 years or older
2. Low to intermediate grade DCIS or invasive ductal carcinoma
3. Tumor size < 2 cm invasive ductal carcinoma and < 2.5 cm DCIS
4. Well defined lumpectomy cavity on CT
5. Clear surgical ink margins > 2mm for invasive cancer and > 3 mm for DCIS
6. Node negative
7. Unifocal lesion
8. ER and/or PR positive
9. HER-2 negative
10. BRCA negative
11. Lumpectomy cavity must be < 30% of whole breast volume
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Lobular histology
2. Angiolymphatic invasion
3. Multiple foci of disease
4. Lymphovascular invasion
5. Active lupus or sarcoid
6. Distant metastases
7. Non-epithelial malignancies
8. Synchronous contralateral breast cancer
9. Grade 2 or higher oncoplastic surgery
10. Ipsilateral pacemaker
11. Ipsilateral breast implant
12. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy
13. Prior ipsilateral breast cancer or thoracic radiation
14. Poor breast integrity
15. Paget's Disease of the nipple
16. Pregnant patients
17. Severe cardiac, pulmonary, or liver diseases
